awd_titl_txt: DEVELOPING AND INTEGRATING "-OMIC" TOOLS TO ELUCIDATE NANOPARTICLE TRANSPORT MECHANISM AND RESPONSES IN AGRICULTURAL CROPS
awd_abstract_narration:
Nanotechnology has gained considerable attention in agricultural applications, due to the unique properties of materials at the nanoscale. Nanomaterials also exhibit an ability to bypass biological barriers. These novel materials may elicit beneficial as well as undesirable responses depending on their composition, method of application, dose or the sensitivity of the crop species. There is limited understanding of how plants respond to these nanomaterials, how they take them up, and at what point the application results in undesirable effects. The project utilizes sensitive bio-analytical tools to study the response of plants to different doses of nanomaterials. The knowledge obtained from this study should serve to design safer nano-scale agrochemicals, improve their effectiveness and promote agricultural sustainability by reducing the use of active ingredients and undesirable accumulation of agrochemicals in soil and associated water bodies. The overarching goal of this research is to apply advanced analytical methods to understand   potential challenges in agriculture that can improve crop productivity and health, while minimizing burden on overall environmental health. 

The proposed project will employ sensitive molecular "nomics" approaches to elucidate the mechanisms of uptake of metal oxide nanoparticles by crop plants and plant response at different doses. Multi-omic tools considered include high-throughput proteomics and metabolomics using advanced liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry. These tools will be used to probe the interactions at the protein and metabolite levels in plants exposed to metal oxide nanoparticles such as copper hydroxide, molybdenum oxide, manganese oxide and cerium oxide via foliar and soil application. Plasma-membrane proteins and apoplastic proteins are critical candidates for this study as they participate in communication between cells and the extracellular environment, ion transport, protein translocation/integration, and signal transduction. These protein in roots and leaves may be selectively enriched in the sample pool, helping to elucidate the main transport pathways. Analysis of hydrophilic and hydrophobic metabolites will also be fractionated for untargeted metabolomics. The candidate proteins and metabolites from untargeted -omic approach will be validated and quantified using targeted approaches across different exposure periods and concentrations, followed by meta-data integration to identify universal biomarkers of metal oxide nanoparticle exposure. The findings will provide a more comprehensive understanding of the routes of entry and localization of nanoparticles and simultaneous regulation of essential nutrients and plant metabolites. The results obtained will provide a benchmark for future research on targeted delivery of nutrients or other agrochemicals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit

The main objective of this project was to understand how plants respond to exposure to different manufactured nanomaterials, not only at the physiological level (for example, biomass weight), but at a much deeper level, using advanced analytical techniques. We developed innovative approaches that reveal how exposure leads to changes at the metabolic level (metabolomics) and the proteins that regulate the metabolic processes (proteomics). These molecular-level analytical techniques allow us to detect even subtle changes in response to exposure levels (dose) that are too low to detect physiologically, or too early to demonstrate themselves in a visible manner. The changes may be beneficial or detrimental to the plant. Having this information serves to guide the development of more finely tuned nanomaterials that can promote the benefits and minimize the negative effects.

A particularly important aspect of our novel approach is the use of a much more quantitative method for detecting the changes in metabolites and proteins, clearly identifying the molecules we are interested in tracking through the exposure. This targeted approach can be used to more specifically explore hypotheses, such as the quantitative changes in different metabolic pathways. While our main project focused on crop plants of significant importance (e.g., corn, wheat, soybean), we collaborated with a number of colleagues around the world to determine the effects of manufactured nanomaterials on aquatic phytoplankton, also at the metabolic level. We demonstrated that our targeted metabolomics platform can serve to answer questions in a very different situation, with clear results.

Specific results from these studies are that:

(1) the method of exposure, whether via the root system or leaves (foliar exposure) is key for determining the level of response by the plant to the specific nanomaterial. This may important if the nanomaterial is intended as a nanofertilizer (such as molybdenum-based nanoparticles) or a nanopesticide (such as nanocopper-based materials), since the effectiveness of the application will be very different depending on the method of exposure.

(2) the use of surfactants is very important for a successful deposition of the nanomaterial formulation onto plant leaves, since many plant leaves (e.g., wheat, corn, soybean) are very water-repellant (hydrophobic). If the nanomaterial is applied in a simple water suspension, the nanofertilizer or nanopesticide may quickly runoff from the leaves, resulting in minimal exposure and much lower effectiveness. Thus, the plant-nano interactions via leaves are strongly dependent on the presence of an adequate surfactant.

(3) Some nanomaterials, or the ions released from them, will be rapidly translocated (i.e., transported) from the leaves to the roots or vice versa, such as molybdenum-based nanomaterials, while others such as copper hydroxide nanoparticles exhibit very low levels of translocation. Thus, the application needs to be tailored to the characteristics of the nanomaterials, which are not only a function of the elemental composition of the nanomaterial, but also of the aqueous media where they are applied (e.g., soil leachate or plant leaves). In our studies, we characterized the behavior of four nanomaterials considered for use in agriculture, namely nano-CeO2, nano-Mn3O4, nano-Cu(OH)2 and nano-MoO3.

4) In terms of the metabolic response, we found that certain metabolic pathways were the most perturbed, positively or negatively, such as those related to energy production, carbohydrate metabolism and amino acid metabolism, as well as oxidative stress, photosynthesis, energy production, and fatty acid metabolism in leaves. The response is strongly influenced by the type of nanomaterial. For example, while copper-based nanomaterials elicit a response to oxidative stress, molybdenum oxide nanoparticles do not. On the other hand, molybdenum-based particles enhance nitrogen metabolism (e.g., amino acid synthesis).

5) Silver nanoparticles can also elicit a strong oxidative stress response, forcing aquatic phytoplankton to produce metabolites that help them defend against this stress, employ antioxidants to minimize the damage, and employing energy that could be used for growth or reproduction.

Broader impacts

Overall, these findings will help nanomaterial scientists to develop safer, more effective nanomaterials for agriculture. The “omics” techniques developed in this project will be useful for improving environmental toxicology, biomedicine and other disciplines that rely on a quantitative understanding of the biological response to a chemical (e.g., medicines, emerging contaminants).

The project also trained a new generation of scientists (three undergraduates, one doctoral student and one postdoctoral researcher) on the use of these novel approaches to understand the nano-bio interface.
